title: Lindelöf's lemma
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, Lindelöf's lemma is a simple but useful <a href="Lemma%20%28mathematics%29">lemma</a> in <a href="topology">topology</a> on the <a href="real%20line">real line</a>, named for the <a href="Finland">Finnish</a> <a href="mathematician">mathematician</a> <a href="Ernst%20Leonard%20Lindel%C3%B6f">Ernst Leonard Lindelöf</a>.
Statement of the lemma.
Let the real line have its standard topology. Then every <a href="Open%20set">open</a> <a href="subset">subset</a> of the real line is a <a href="Countable%20set">countable</a> <a href="Union%20%28set%20theory%29">union</a> of open <a href="Interval%20%28mathematics%29">interval</a>s.
Generalized Statement.
Lindelöf's lemma is also known as the statement that every open cover in a <a href="second-countable%20space">second-countable space</a> has a countable <a href="cover%20%28topology%29">subcover</a> (Kelley 1955:49). This means that every <a href="second-countable%20space">second-countable space</a> is also a <a href="Lindel%C3%B6f%20space">Lindelöf space</a>.
